description: N-Representability Constraints leverage fundamental physical constraints on reduced density matrices (RDMs) from quantum chemistry to remove unphysical noise artifacts. Any valid quantum state must produce RDMs that satisfy a hierarchy of conditions known as N-representability conditions.

The most commonly used are the 2-positive conditions (P, Q, G conditions on the 2-RDM), which require certain matrices derived from the 2-RDM to be positive semidefinite. Noisy quantum devices can produce RDMs that violate these conditions, and projecting onto the feasible set effectively removes the unphysical noise component.

This technique is purely classical post-processing: the quantum device produces a noisy estimate of the RDM, and a semidefinite program (SDP) finds the nearest N-representable RDM. It requires no additional quantum measurements beyond those needed for the RDM.
how_it_works: Measure the elements of the 2-body reduced density matrix (2-RDM) \(\Gamma_{pq,rs} = \langle a_p^\dagger a_q^\dagger a_s a_r \rangle\) on the quantum device.
Check whether the measured 2-RDM satisfies N-representability conditions (P, Q, G conditions). Noisy estimates typically violate these.
Formulate a semidefinite program: find the nearest 2-RDM (in Frobenius norm) that satisfies all N-representability constraints.
Compute corrected expectation values (e.g., energy) from the projected 2-RDM: \(E = \sum_{pqrs} h_{pqrs} \Gamma_{pq,rs}\).

key_equations.label: 2-RDM energy (h = Hamiltonian coefficients, Γ = 2-body RDM, γ = 1-body RDM, a†/a = fermionic creation/annihilation operators)

bias_variance.notes: Purely classical post-processing, so no additional quantum overhead. Bias reduction depends on how tight the N-representability constraints are. Variance is essentially unchanged since no additional measurements are needed.

advantages: No additional quantum measurements or circuit modifications required
No noise model needed — uses fundamental physical constraints
Purely classical post-processing (SDP solvers are mature)
Provably removes unphysical contributions from noisy RDMs
disadvantages: Only applicable to fermionic / quantum chemistry problems with RDM structure
SDP complexity grows with system size (though polynomial)
N-representability conditions are necessary but not sufficient — projection may over-constrain
Cannot correct errors that produce valid-looking RDMs
use_cases: Post-processing VQE results for molecular energy calculations
Combined with symmetry verification for additional constraint enforcement
Reducing noise in reduced density matrix measurements
